Existence of files or paths containing t.Data: Windows Event ID 4663; Windows Event ID 4656; Zeek file.log
Existence of files or paths containing t.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4663 (access), 4656 (handle request), and Zeek file.log for filenames or paths containing the Unicode character \u202E or its representations (%E2%80%AE). Use string matching and regular expressions to identify these patterns. Use descriptive statistics on the frequency of file events containing this character to identify unusual occurrences on specific systems or network segments.

RTLO character found within registry key.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4657 (registry value write) for registry key or value names containing the RTLO character. Analyze Zeek file.log for common malicious file extensions (e.g., .exe, .scr, .js) transmitted over the network and inspect corresponding filenames for the RTLO character. Correlate findings with observed process creation events if available to understand the outcome.

Process execution events where the execu.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 (Process Creation) for events where the 'New Process Name' or 'Command Line' fields contain the Unicode character \u202E or its representations. Use string matching and regular expressions to identify the character and analyze the potential filename manipulation. Use frequency analysis on these events to identify rare or unusual process executions.

Detection of file transfers over the net.Data: Zeek http.log; Zeek smb_files.log; Zeek file.log
Detection of file transfers over the net.Action: Analyze Zeek logs (http.log, smb_files.log, file.log) for file transfers where the filename field contains the \u202E Unicode character. Identify instances where the actual filename contains an executable extension (e.g., .exe, .scr) but the sequence of characters around the RTLO would cause it to display with a benign extension (e.g., .jpg, .pdf). Use descriptive statistics (counts, source/destination) on such transfers to identify suspicious patterns.
